PUBLISHED : 26 Feb 2016 at 10:41 WRITER: 
														Pratuan Kajonvuthinun and Online Reporters Temperatures in the upper part of the country will drop by another 1-3 degree Celsius by Sunday while strong winds and high waves are expected to batter the South, the Meteorological Department warned on Friday. A strong high pressure front from China has extended over Thailand and the South China Sea and is likely to blanket the country until Feb 28. It will cause temperatures in the North to drop between 1-3 degree Celsius and 1-2 degrees Celsius in the Northeast, the Central Plain and East during the period, according to the weather forecast issued today. The northeast monsoon across the Gulf of Thailand and the South is intensifying. Strong winds and waves between 2-4 metres are expected to hit the Gulf of Thailand during this period. The department warned that people should beware of onshore surf. All ships should proceed with caution and small boats should stay ashore between today and Sunday. Between Feb 29 and March 2, the high pressure areas covering upper part of Thailand are expected to weaken, the department predicted. Cool weather will remain in the upper part of the country, however. The northeast monsoon prevailing over the Gulf of Thailand and the South will weaken. In the upper Northeast, minimum temperatures ranged between 12-16 Celsius Friday with highs hitting 25-28 degrees. In mountainous areas, temps were recorded at 5-12 Celsius, according to the weather forecast agency in the upper North. In Sakon Nakhon, a cold spell has gripped mountainous areas in Phu Phan, Nikhom Nam Un, Song Dao and Tao Ngoi districts since Thursday night.
